texts.content_text20: Ethical considerations always reflect the social, cultural, political, and economic context.  As a result, they produce an amalgam of basic elements: human nature, community values, personal philosophy or beliefs, and professional socialization. These elements may produce endless combinations of ethical behaviour.
texts.content_text21: In different contexts, different ethical judgements may arise. Therefore, ethical dilemmas can be approached in several ways: by assessing their outcome, by focusing on the act itself, or by considering the character of the agent.
texts.content_text200: Lina is a 10-year-old girl who recently moved to the country with her mother and her mother’s partner.
texts.content_text201: Her teacher notices that Lina has become withdrawn, often appears tired, and has difficulty concentrating in class.
texts.content_text202: One day, after a classroom activity about safety and trust, Lina quietly tells the school counsellor that she is afraid to go home because her mother’s partner “gets angry and shouts” and sometimes locks her in her room as punishment.
texts.content_text203: Lina speaks limited local language, is unfamiliar with legal procedures, and becomes anxious when asked repeated questions. She worries that telling her story will “get her mum in trouble.”
